title: 110_s665
content: The Secretary of Transportation is limited to making loans of up to $1,000,000,000 over a 5-year period without approval from Congress. Loans exceeding this limit must be approved by Congress within 6 months of notice. (a) Contents of Resolution.--A joint resolution introduced after Congress receives notice from the Secretary of Transportation must approve a specific loan. (b) Referral to Committee.--Resolutions in the House go to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, while Senate resolutions go to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. Resolutions cannot be reported before the 8th day after introduction. (c) Discharge of Committee.--If referred, the committee must act on the resolution. If a resolution is not reported by the committee within 15 days of introduction, it will be placed on the House calendar. Once a resolution is reported or discharged from committee, any Member can move for its consideration on the floor, with all points of order waived. The motion for consideration of the resolution is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. A motion to reconsider the vote is not allowed. If the motion to proceed is agreed to, the resolution remains unfinished business. Debate is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing the resolution. The motion for consideration of the resolution is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and privileged in the Senate. It is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. Debate is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between those in favor and those opposing the resolution. A motion further to limit debate is in order and not debatable. An amendment to, or a motion to postpone, or a motion to proceed to the consideration of other business, or a motion to recommit the resolution is not in order. A motion to reconsider the vote by which the resolution is agreed to or disagreed to is not in order. Vote on final passage shall occur immediately following the conclusion of the debate. Rulings of the chair on procedure are subject to appeals. Decisions of the Chair regarding the application of rules in the Senate or House of Representatives for a resolution are made without debate. If one House receives a resolution from the other House, it will not be referred to a committee, and the procedures for the receiving House will remain the same. The final vote will be on the resolution itself. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate regarding the passage of a resolution are enacted by Congress, allowing each House to change its rules related to the resolution's procedure. The Act will be effective starting January 1, 2007.
